https://web.archive.org/web/20091013031644/http://health.act.gov.au/c/health?a=&did=11044035| archivedate= 13 October 2009 | deadurl= no}} |n/a |n/a |- |align=left|'''[[New South Wales]]''' |5,078{{cite web|url=http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/2009/20090903_00.html |title=Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 Influenza Update |date=3 September 2009 |accessdate=3 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090904230847/http://www.health.nsw.gov.au/news/2009/20090903_00.html |archivedate=4 September 2009 }} |n/a |n/a |- |align=left|'''[[Northern Territory]]''' |1,456{{cite web|url=http://www.health.nt.gov.au/H1N1_Influenza/index.aspx |title=H1N1 Influenza – Human Swine Flu |publisher=Northern Territory Government Department of Health and Families |date=25 September 2009 |accessdate=27 September 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012165112/http://www.health.nt.gov.au/H1N1_Influenza/index.aspx |archivedate=12 October 2009 |deadurl=yes }} |n/a |n/a |- |align=left|'''[[Queensland]]''' |11,528{{cite web |url=http://www.health.qld.gov.au/swineflu/documents/flu_qld_week_21092009.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uTpzKeCO?url=http://www.health.qld.gov.au/swineflu/documents/flu_qld_week_21092009.pdf |archivedate=24 November 2010 |title=Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 Pandemic in Queensland 2009 weekly report 38 |at=table 1 |date=21 September 2009 |accessdate=27 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} |n/a |n/a |- |align=left|'''[[South Australia]]''' |8,944{{cite web|url=http://www.flu.sa.gov.au/|title=Stopping the spread of Flu starts here|date=29 September 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090929163748/http://flu.sa.gov.au/| archivedate= 29 September 2009 | deadurl= no}} |n/a |n/a |- |align=left|'''[[Tasmania]]''' |3,204 |n/a |n/a |- |align=left|'''[[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]]''' |3,058{{cite web|url=http://humanswineflu.health.vic.gov.au/|title=H1N1 Influenza 09 (Human Swine Flu)|date=30 September 2009|accessdate=2 October 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20091007035154/http://humanswineflu.health.vic.gov.au/| archivedate= 7 October 2009 | deadurl= no}} |n/a |n/a |- |align=left|'''[[Western Australia]]''' |4,499{{cite web|url=http://www.health.wa.gov.au/swine_flu/home/|title=Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 – Human Swine Flu|accessdate=2 October 2008|date=29 September 2008|publisher=Government of Western Australia}} |n/a |n/a |} As at 18 December 2009, [[Australia]] had 37,537 confirmed cases of [[2009 swine flu outbreak|H1N1 Influenza 2009 (Human Swine Influenza)]] and 191 deaths reported by Department of Health but only 77 deaths reported by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.{{cite web|title=Diseases of the Respiratory System (J00-J99)|url=http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/0/1CFA8B66386B6C04CA2579C6000F7030?opendocument|website=Australian Bureau of Statistics|accessdate=2018-02-15|date=20 March 2012}} The actual numbers are much larger, as only serious cases are being tested and treated. Suspected cases have not been reported by the [[Department of Health and Ageing]] since 18 May 2009 because they are changing too quickly to report.{{cite video |people=[[Nicola Roxon]], [[Minister for Health and Ageing (Australia)]] |date=27 May 2009|title=Press conference |url=http://ten.com.au/video-player.htm?vxSiteId=cb519624-44a2-4bf7-808b-3514d34e96e4&vxChannel=NEWS&vxClipId=1427_news-roxon-270509&vxBitrate=300&CMP=LEC-DANCEgetVideoLink|medium=Television production |publisher=Network Ten |location=Australia |accessdate=27 May 2009 |time=2:55| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090619174034/http://ten.com.au/video-player.htm?vxSiteId=cb519624-44a2-4bf7-808b-3514d34e96e4&vxChannel=NEWS&vxClipId=1427_news-roxon-270509&vxBitrate=300&CMP=LEC-DANCEgetVideoLink| archivedate= 19 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} As many as 1600 Australians may have died as a result of this virus.{{cite journal|last1=Dawood|first1=FS|last2=Iuliano|first2=AD|last3=Reed|first3=C|last4=Meltzer|first4=MI|last5=Shay|first5=DK|last6=Cheng|first6=PY|last7=Bandaranayake|first7=D|last8=Breiman|first8=RF|last9=Brooks|first9=WA|last10=Buchy|first10=P|last11=Feikin|first11=DR|last12=Fowler|first12=KB|last13=Gordon|first13=A|last14=Hien|first14=NT|last15=Horby|first15=P|last16=Huang|first16=QS|last17=Katz|first17=MA|last18=Krishnan|first18=A|last19=Lal|first19=R|last20=Montgomery|first20=JM|last21=Mølbak|first21=K|last22=Pebody|first22=R|last23=Presanis|first23=AM|last24=Razuri|first24=H|last25=Steens|first25=A|last26=Tinoco|first26=YO|last27=Wallinga|first27=J|last28=Yu|first28=H|last29=Vong|first29=S|last30=Bresee|first30=J|last31=Widdowson|first31=MA|title=Estimated global mortality associated with the first 12 months of 2009 pandemic influenza A H1N1 virus circulation: a modelling study|journal=The Lancet. Infectious Diseases|date=September 2012|volume=12|issue=9|pages=687–95|doi=10.1016/S1473-3099(12)70121-4|pmid=22738893}}{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/health/swine-flu-death-toll-might-be-revised-up/story-fn59nokw-1226409559471|work=The Australian}}{{subscription required}} On 23 May The federal government classified the outbreak as CONTAIN phase except in [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] where it was escalated to the SUSTAIN phase on 3 June.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25581118-2702,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090620031038/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0%2C25197%2C25581118-2702%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 June 2009 |title=Victoria raises swine flu risk alert to sustain |date=3 June 2009 |accessdate=6 June 2009 |publisher=[[The Australian]] |first=Siobhain |last=Ryan |df= }} This gives government authorities permission to close schools to slow the spread of the disease.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/23/2579007.htm|title=Rudd defends swine flu threat upgrade|date=23 May 2009|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=23 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090527085158/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/23/2579007.htm| archivedate= 27 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On 17 June 2009 the Department of Health and Ageing introduced a new phase called PROTECT. This modified the response to focus on people with high risk of complications from the disease. Testing at airports is to be discontinued. The national stockpile of antiviral drugs will no longer be made available to people with the flu unless there are more than mild symptoms or a high risk of dying.{{cite web|url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/resources/$File/090617%20protect%20media%20release%20FINAL.pdf |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uTpzO6Qg?url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/resources/%24File/090617%20protect%20media%20release%20FINAL.pdf |archivedate=24 November 2010 |title=New Pandemic Phase Protect |author=[[Nicola Roxon]] |date=17 June 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Australia has a stockpile of 8.7 million doses of [[Tamiflu]] and [[Relenza]].{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/70-australians-tested-for-swine-flu-20090428-alvp.html?page=-1 |title=70 Australians tested for swine flu |publisher=AAP |accessdate=28 April 2009 | location=Melbourne | date=29 April 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090430094929/http://www.theage.com.au/national/70-australians-tested-for-swine-flu-20090428-alvp.html?page=-1| archivedate= 30 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} Under the earlier DELAY and CONTAIN phases Airlines were required to report passengers with [[influenza]] symptoms, and [[thermal imaging]] and nurses were deployed at international airports. Passengers arriving were required to fill in a health declaration card.{{cite web|url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/health-swine_influenza-index.htm |title=Health Emergency–H1N1 Influenza 09 (Human Swine Influenza)Outbreaks |publisher=Healthemergency.gov.au |date= |accessdate=6 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090502001704/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/health-swine_influenza-index.htm| archivedate= 2 May 2009 | deadurl= yes}} A large scale immunization effort against swine flu started on Monday 28 September 2009. == Context == There are on average 2,500-3,000 deaths every year as a result of seasonal influenza in Australia. An estimated 1 billion are infected seasonally, throughout the world. In Australia, 37,537 swine flu tests have given positive results and there have been 191 confirmed deaths of people infected with swine flu as of 18 December 2009. == Reported cases == === Queensland === On 9 May 2009, Australia confirmed its first case of swine flu in a 33-year-old woman, when she touched down from a flight from [[Los Angeles]] to [[Brisbane]]. Although it was confirmed to be not infectious (coming out as a "weak but positive result"), family members and people who were sitting close to her during the flight have been contacted and urged to seek immediate medical attention if they began to show flu-like symptoms.{{cite news|title=First confirmed case of swine flu in Australia |publisher=News.com.au |date=9 May 2009 |url=http://www.news.com.au/story/0,27574,25452286-5018988,00.html |accessdate=9 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090511005950/http://www.news.com.au/story/0%2C27574%2C25452286-5018988%2C00.html |archivedate=11 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }} On 24 May [[Queensland]] confirmed its second case.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/24/2579412.htm|title=Australia confirms 17th case of swine flu|date=24 May 2009|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=24 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090527003346/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/24/2579412.htm| archivedate= 27 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} 41 deaths have been recorded in Queensland. The first person to die in Queensland was a 38-year-old woman who died on 15 July at the [[Mater Hospital Pimlico]].{{cite web |url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-150709 |title=More deaths in Australia |format= |publisher=[[Department of Health and Ageing]] |date=15 July 2009 |accessdate=15 July 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090715203405/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-150709| archivedate= 15 July 2009 | deadurl= yes}} === Victoria === In [[Victoria, Australia|Victoria]] there have been 2,440 cases, including 24 deaths. An 11-year-old boy, and later his 2 brothers, were confirmed on 20 May to carry the virus.{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/swine-flu-three-brothers-test-positive-20090520-bf2q.html|title=Swine flu: Three brothers test positive|date=20 May 2009|publisher=The Age Melbourne|accessdate=20 May 2009 | first1=Mex | last1=Cooper | first2=Nick | last2=Miller| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090521194018/http://www.theage.com.au/national/swine-flu-three-brothers-test-positive-20090520-bf2q.html| archivedate= 21 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} Victorian health authorities closed [[Clifton Hill, Victoria|Clifton Hill]] Primary School for two days on 21 May, initially, after the three brothers returned to the school from a trip to [[Disneyland]].{{cite news | title = Swine flu outbreak closes school | publisher = smh.com.au | date = 21 May 2009 | url =http://www.smh.com.au/national/swine-flu-outbreak-closes-school-20090521-bfyw.html | accessdate = 21 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090523210800/http://www.smh.com.au/national/swine-flu-outbreak-closes-school-20090521-bfyw.html| archivedate= 23 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} A further case delayed the reopening of the school until Thursday 28 May 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/23/2579053.htm |title=Classmates treated as swine flu spreads |date=23 May 2009 |work=ABC News |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=23 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090530000337/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/23/2579053.htm |archivedate=30 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/28/2582786.htm|title=School re-opens after swine flu outbreak|date=28 May 2009|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=28 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090531074348/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/28/2582786.htm| archivedate= 31 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} On 23 May about 22 year-nine students of [[Mill Park Secondary College]] were given anti-viral Tamiflu after one of their classmates was diagnosed with swine flu, the same happened for students in year 9 at the University High School in Parkville and also for the Melton campus of [[Mowbray College]] after a year 10 student contracted the virus . A 35-year-old man from [[Colac, Victoria|Colac]] died on 20 June 2009 at [[City of Maroondah|Maroondah]] Hospital after going to Colac Hospital the previous day.{{cite web| title=Second H1N1 Influenza 09 related death – Victoria |publisher= [[Department of Health and Ageing]] | url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-230609-3 | date=23 June 2009 | accessdate=23 June 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090624225653/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-230609-3| archivedate= 24 June 2009 | deadurl= yes}} On 23 June 2009, the second swine flu related death in Victoria was reported, in that of a 50-year-old woman at the [[Peter MacCallum Cancer Centre]].{{cite web| title=Second death in Victoria |publisher= [[Department of Health and Ageing]] | url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-240609 | date=24 June 2009 | accessdate=24 June 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090624225627/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-240609| archivedate= 24 June 2009 | deadurl= yes}} A third death was reported on 25 June.{{cite news| title=Fourth swine flu victim dies|publisher= [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] | url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/06/26/2609753.htm?site=news | date=26 June 2009 | accessdate=26 June 2009 }} Two more death were reported on the weekend of 27 and 28 June.{{cite web| title=Two more H1N1 Influenza 09 deaths in Victoria, brings national total to seven | publisher= [[Department of Health and Ageing]] | url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-290609 | date=24 June 2009 | accessdate=24 June 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090701200242/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-290609| archivedate= 1 July 2009 | deadurl= yes}} Two more deaths were reported on 1 July, including a 3 year old.{{cite web| title=Two further deaths in Victoria |publisher= [[Department of Health and Ageing]] | url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-081 |date= 1 July 2009|accessdate=1 July 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090701200316/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-081| archivedate= 1 July 2009 | deadurl= yes}} Four more deaths were recorded on 8 July.{{cite news|title=Victoria records 4 more swine flu deaths|publisher =[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/07/08/2620387.htm |date=8 July 2009 | accessdate=8 July 2009}} The SUSTAIN phase in Victoria means that less effort will be given to tracing and testing, as there would be insufficient resources available to do this. Antiviral drugs in this phase are only available to confirmed cases or their immediate contacts. === New South Wales === In [[New South Wales]] there have been 51 deaths. The first confirmed death in New South Wales occurred on 29 June{{cite web|url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-020709 |title=First NSW death |publisher=[[Department of Health and Ageing]] |date=2 July 2009 |accessdate=2 July 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090703131404/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-020709| archivedate= 3 July 2009 | deadurl= yes}} and a second man died on 3 July.{{cite web |url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-050709 |title=Second death in NSW |format= |publisher=[[Department of Health and Ageing]] |date=5 July 2009 |accessdate=6 July 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090708211927/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-050709| archivedate= 8 July 2009 | deadurl= yes}} === South Australia === [[South Australia]] has recorded 28 deaths, plus a 'clinical positive' where the test was inconclusive and, after swine-flu-like symptoms were reported, Tamiflu was administered, thus making a future positive confirmation unlikely.{{cite web|url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/health/817351/sa-boy-clinical-positive-to-swine-flu|title=SA boy 'clinical positive' to swine flu|last=AAP|date=24 May 2009|work=9 News|publisher=ninemsn.com.au|accessdate=24 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090527111013/http://news.ninemsn.com.au/health/817351/sa-boy-clinical-positive-to-swine-flu| archivedate= 27 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} Adelaide high schools [[Eynesbury Senior College]] and [[Blackfriars Priory School]] closed for a week.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/22/2577717.htm|title=10th swine flu case confirmed|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=22 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090525095457/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/22/2577717.htm| archivedate= 25 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} The first confirmed death from swine flu in Australia was a 26-year-old [[Indigenous Australian|Aboriginal man]] from [[Kiwirrkurra Community, Western Australia|Kiwirrkurra Community]] in the [[Western Desert cultural bloc|Western Desert]] of Western Australia who died in [[Royal Adelaide Hospital]] on 19 June. === Australian Capital Territory === The [[Australian Capital Territory]] has recorded two deaths and 920 confirmed cases by 28 August 2009. Two of the earliest casualties contracted the disease while on the [[Pacific Dawn (ship)|Pacific Dawn]] cruise ship.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/28/2582774.htm|title=More swine flu cases inevitable: Gallagher|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=28 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090531064928/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/28/2582774.htm| archivedate= 31 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} The first death in the ACT occurred on 28 July 2009.{{cite web |url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-010809 |title=First Pandemic (H1N1) 2009 influenza related death in the ACT |publisher=[[Department of Health and Ageing]] |date=1 August 2009 |accessdate=1 August 2009 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090806001550/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-010809| archivedate= 6 August 2009 | deadurl= yes}}
During the last week of July 2009, Radford College's year 12 cohort was asked to stay home, after a spike of influenza through the year. === Western Australia === There have been 27 confirmed deaths in [[Western Australia]]. The first person to die in the state was a 26-year-old woman who died on 26 June 2009. A 26-year-old Western Australian man died in Adelaide on 19 June. === Tasmania === Tasmania has recorded seven deaths. Public health authorities expected up to 200,000 Tasmanians could catch swine flu in the three months incoming from June.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/06/03/2587924.htm|title=40 per cent of Tasmanians predicted to contract swine flu|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=3 June 2009|accessdate=3 June 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090614095805/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/06/03/2587924.htm| archivedate= 14 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} The first person to die in Tasmania was an 85-year-old woman who died in [[Royal Hobart Hospital]] on 5 July.{{cite web |url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-070709 |title=First death in Tasmania |format= |publisher=[[Department of Health and Ageing]] |date=7 July 2009 |accessdate=7 July 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090708212007/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-070709| archivedate= 8 July 2009 | deadurl= yes}} === Northern Territory === The [[Northern Territory]] confirmed the first infection of a person on 30 May 2009.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/31/2585459.htm|title=NT records first swine flu case|work=ABC News|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=31 May 2009|accessdate=31 May 2009}} Six people have died in the territory so far. The first person in the Territory to die from the current epidemic was a man in his early 50s who died at the [[Royal Darwin Hospital]] on 6 July.{{cite web |url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-060709 |title=First Northern Territory death |format= |publisher=[[Department of Health and Ageing]] |date=6 July 2009 |accessdate=6 July 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090708211914/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/news-060709| archivedate= 8 July 2009 | deadurl= yes}} === Overseas cases === The swine flu has also affected some Australians internationally: :Three Australians in London had confirmed cases of swine flu.{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/science/third-aussie-tests-positive-for-swine-flu-in-london-report-20090504-arnj.html?page=-1|title=Third Aussie tests positive for swine flu in London: report|last=AAP|date=4 May 2009|work=SMH|publisher=Fairfax|accessdate=25 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090505004318/http://www.smh.com.au/world/science/third-aussie-tests-positive-for-swine-flu-in-london-report-20090504-arnj.html?page=-1| archivedate= 5 May 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25417418-601,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503033130/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0%2C25197%2C25417418-601%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 May 2009 |title=Two Australians test positive for swine flu in London |last=AAP |date=2 May 2009 |work=The Australian |publisher=News Limited |accessdate=25 May 2009 |df= }} :Australians in [[quarantine]]:{{cite video |people=[[Nicola Roxon]], [[Minister for Health and Ageing (Australia)]] |date=27 May 2009|title=Press conference |url=http://ten.com.au/video-player.htm?vxSiteId=cb519624-44a2-4bf7-808b-3514d34e96e4&vxChannel=NEWS&vxClipId=1427_news-roxon-270509&vxBitrate=300&CMP=LEC-DANCEgetVideoLink|medium=Television production |publisher=Network Ten |location=Australia |accessdate=27 May 2009 |time=8:50| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090619174034/http://ten.com.au/video-player.htm?vxSiteId=cb519624-44a2-4bf7-808b-3514d34e96e4&vxChannel=NEWS&vxClipId=1427_news-roxon-270509&vxBitrate=300&CMP=LEC-DANCEgetVideoLink| archivedate= 19 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} *7 in [[South Korea]] *7 in [[China]] including 1 confirmed case *1 confirmed case in [[Taiwan]]; recovered and released *2, a mother and child, in the [[Philippines]] *1 confirmed case of a 12-year-old boy in [[Singapore]] who began showing symptoms while on a flight from [[Sydney]] === Pacific Dawn cruise ship swine flu scare === {{Cleanup rewrite|2=section|date=December 2013}} On 25 May, about 3 hours after going off the boat, a swine flu scare was reported on board. This shock has caused a spark in the number of cases, going up much more rapidly than before, and somehow causing "Case 1" (see above). The number of cases was around 20 before the scare, and due to this, the amount of cases have risen well over 15,000. This cruise ship caused almost half of the cases in SA, caused the WA case, and the TAS case. Also it caused a scare in [[New Caledonia]]. == Government travel advice == Borders have not been closed, and no restrictions have been placed on travel.[http://www.smarttraveller.gov.au/zw-cgi/view/TravelBulletins/Health-Swine_Influenza Travel Bulletin: Health : Swine Influenza] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503021145/http://www.smarttraveller.gov.au/zw-cgi/view/TravelBulletins/Health-Swine_Influenza |date=3 May 2009 }} Travel to countries with confirmed cases of swine flu have not been reclassed to reconsider, as at 1 May 2009. == Measures to control an outbreak == Starting from 30 April thermal imaging was applied to passenger arrivals at international airports and arriving passengers were required to fill in a card. Customs officers checked aeroplane cabins prior to disembarkation of passengers looking for people with flu symptoms.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/01/2557672.htm |title=Flu fears spark rush on pharmacies |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=1 May 2009 |accessdate=6 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503154757/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/01/2557672.htm |archivedate=3 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }} On 23 May the government upgraded the flu alert level from "delay" to "contain", giving authorities in all states the option to close schools if students were at risk. All states and territories have ordered students returning from countries where flu was widespread (Canada, Japan, Mexico, Panama and United States) not to return to school for a week after entering Australia.{{cite news |url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/australian-swine-flu-cases-rise-to-31-20090526-bkz2.html |title=Australian swine flu cases rise to 31 |date=26 May 2009 |publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|accessdate=26 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090619141809/http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-national/australian-swine-flu-cases-rise-to-31-20090526-bkz2.html| archivedate= 19 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} States outside Victoria decided to prevent students returning to school for a week if they have visited Victoria.{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,25584064-2702,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090606195627/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0%2C25197%2C25584064-2702%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=6 June 2009 |title=Victoria placed on swine flu blacklist |date=4 June 2009 |accessdate=4 June 2009 |work=The Australian |first=Siobhain |last=Ryan |df= }} [[CSL Limited]] started to produce a vaccine to immunize against swine flu, and received an order from the Australian Government for ten million doses. The inoculations are expected to be ready around the end of July 2009.{{cite news |url=http://bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601124&sid=au.0.96Ap54Q&refer=home |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120630042803/http://bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601124&sid=au.0.96Ap54Q&refer=home |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 June 2012 |title=CSL to start making swine flu vaccine next week for human tests |author=Simeon Bennett |publisher=Bloomberg |date=26 May 2009 |accessdate=28 May 2009}}{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2008/s2583673.htm |title=Government orders vaccines as swine flu cases 100 |date=28 May 2009 |author=Alison Caldwell, [[Nicola Roxon]] |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=28 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090619204717/http://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2008/s2583673.htm| archivedate= 19 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} In Melbourne, seven special clinics for influenza opened on 29 May.{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/29/2584210.htm |title=Seven swine flu clinics open in Melbourne |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=29 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090612063904/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/05/29/2584210.htm| archivedate= 12 June 2009 | deadurl= no}} There are now additional measures to control the flu outbreak encouraging students returning from Victoria to stay away from school and quarantine themselves for a period of up to seven days. === Preparations === The Australian Government had a stockpile of 40 million surgical grade face masks. However stocks of face masks in pharmacies were depleted due to personal purchases. The [[World Health Organization]] Influenza Centre in North [[Melbourne]] was attempting to develop a vaccine for swine flu, by growing the live virus as found in California, in chicken embryos.{{cite news |last=Brown |first=Rachael |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/04/30/2557409.htm |title=Melbourne lab joins race for flu vaccine |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=30 April 2009 |accessdate=6 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090505171910/http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/04/30/2557409.htm| archivedate= 5 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} The first one-litre batch of vaccine was announced to be ready on 29 June 2009 by the [[University of Queensland]], but would not be available for use until it was registered as safe with the regulatory authority.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/06/29/2611426.htm|title=Qld uni unveils swine flu vaccine|author=Josh Bavas|publisher=ABC News|date=29 June 2009|accessdate=29 June 2009}} A Commonwealth Health [[hotline]] for Swine Influenza was set up on Australian phone number 1802007 by the [[Department of Health and Ageing]].{{cite web |url=http://www.smarttraveller.gov.au/ |title=Smartraveller: The Australian Government's travel advisory and consular assistance service |publisher=Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade |date=4 September 2003 |accessdate=6 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503123058/http://www.smarttraveller.gov.au/| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} The Australian Government set up a health emergency web site. Daily tallies of suspected cases were given.{{cite web |url=http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/updates |title=Update bulletins |publisher=Health Emergency |date= |accessdate=6 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090503233851/http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/internet/healthemergency/publishing.nsf/Content/updates| archivedate= 3 May 2009 | deadurl= yes}} The [[Tasmanian Government]] set up a ''Tasmanian Action Plan for Human Influenza Pandemic''.{{cite web|url=http://www.pandemic.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0016/61801/Tasmanian_Action_Plan_for_Human_Influenza.pdf |title=Tasmanian action plan for human influenza |publisher=[[Tasmanian Government]] |format=PDF |accessdate=28 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090528095002/http://www.pandemic.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0016/61801/Tasmanian_Action_Plan_for_Human_Influenza.pdf |archivedate=28 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} The [[Queensland Government]] had an action plan prepared in 2008{{cite web|url=http://www.qld.gov.au/about/health-and-communities/avian-influenza/pdf/action_plan.pdf |format=PDF |title=Avian influenza action plan |publisher=[[Queensland Government]] |year=2008 |accessdate=28 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090530095543/http://www.qld.gov.au/about/health-and-communities/avian-influenza/pdf/action_plan.pdf |archivedate=30 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} and a [[business continuity plan]] in 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.qld.gov.au/about/health-and-communities/avian-influenza/pdf/business_continuity_plan.pdf |format=PDF |title=Business continuity plan |publisher=[[Queensland Government]] |year=2006 |accessdate=28 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090530095548/http://www.qld.gov.au/about/health-and-communities/avian-influenza/pdf/business_continuity_plan.pdf |archivedate=30 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} The [[Australian Capital Territory]] Chief Medical Officer, Dr Charles Guest, claimed that procedures and systems were very good to detect and respond to the disease outbreak.{{cite web |url=http://www.health.act.gov.au/c/health?a=da&did=10098808&pid=1240874209 |title=H1N1 Flu (Swine Flu) |publisher=ACT Health |date= |accessdate=6 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090505050453/http://www.health.act.gov.au/c/health?a=da&did=10098808&pid=1240874209| archivedate= 5 May 2009 | deadurl= no}} [[South Australia]] has nominated eight hospitals to handle flu: Royal Adelaide, Flinders Medical Centre or Women's and Children's Hospital, Berri, Mount Gambier, Port Lincoln, Whyalla or Port Augusta.{{cite web|url=http://flu.sa.gov.au/Swineflu.aspx |title=Stopping the spread of flu starts here |publisher=Department of Health South Australia |accessdate=28 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090527141620/http://flu.sa.gov.au/Swineflu.aspx |archivedate=27 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The [[Victorian Government]] Department of Human Services had a nurse on call to answer questions on the topic.{{cite web|url=http://www.health.vic.gov.au/ideas/diseases/swine-influenza |title=Swine influenza–influenza A (H1N1) virus |publisher=Communicable Disease Control, Public Health Branch, Rural & Regional Health & Aged Care Services Division of the Victorian State Government, Department of Human Services |accessdate=28 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090528092829/http://www.health.vic.gov.au/ideas/diseases/swine-influenza |archivedate=28 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} === Hygiene recommendations === The Tasmanian government published a warning poster{{cite web|url=http://www.pandemic.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0015/62340/Protect_yourself_from_the_flu_Poster_1.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=28 May 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090528093408/http://www.pandemic.tas.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0015/62340/Protect_yourself_from_the_flu_Poster_1.pdf |archivedate=28 May 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} and a series of recommendations to health professionals on protective equipment, hand washing and sterilisation.{{cite web |url=http://www.pandemic.tas.gov.au/what_does_it_mean_to_you/health_sector |title=Planning for a Pandemic |publisher=Tasmanian Government |date= |accessdate=6 May 2009| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090505194808/http://www.pandemic.tas.gov.au/what_does_it_mean_to_you/health_sector| archivedate= 5 May 2009 | deadurl= yes}} === Evaluation === In a 2011 article in the Emerging Health Threats Journal, [[Peter Collignon]] commented that the media frequently compared the outbreaks to the [[1918 flu pandemic]] that infected 500 million people and killed tens of millions. Widespread public fear of a similar number of deaths lead to "Emergency Departments and doctor surgeries being overwhelmed" with requests for antiviral drugs, jeopardising the supply for the highest risk patients.{{cite journal|vauthors=Collignon P, Doshi P, Del Mar C, Jefferson T | title=Safety and efficacy of inactivated influenza vaccines in children. | journal=Clin Infect Dis | year= 2015 | volume= 60 | issue= 3 | page= 489 | pmid=25344541 | doi=10.1093/cid/ciu835 }} == Statistics == *As at 18 December 2009, there have been 37,537 confirmed cases of pandemic (H1N1) 2009 and 191 deaths reported in Australia according to Department of Health. * In 2009, [[2009 swine flu outbreak|H1N1 Influenza 2009 (Human Swine Influenza)]] was the underlying cause of 77 deaths in Australia. The ABS implemented World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines to code all swine flu deaths to the ICD-10 code of Influenza due to certain identified influenza virus (J09). == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.healthemergency.gov.au/ Australian Department of Health and Ageing "Health Emergency" website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101005124559/http://www.swine-flu-news.us/ Swine Flu News and Updates From Around the World] {{2009 swine flu}} {{Influenza}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} [[Category:2009 in Australia|Flu pandemic]] [[Category:2009 flu pandemic by country|Australia]] [[Category:Health disasters in Australia]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} [[File:Wines in Sabah, Malaysia.JPG|thumb|right|Local [[white wine]] brands in a market in [[Sabah]]. Most of Malaysia's alcohol production centres are located in [[East Malaysia]] as the non-Muslims population are mostly concentrated there.]] '''Alcohol in Malaysia''' refers to the [[alcohol beverage|consumption]], [[alcohol industry|industry]] and [[alcohol law|laws]] of alcohol in the [[Southeast Asia]]n country of [[Malaysia]]. Although Malaysia is a [[Muslim majority countries|Muslim majority country]], the country permits the selling of alcohol to non-Muslims. There are no nationwide alcohol bans being enforced in the country, with the exception of [[Kelantan]] and [[Terengganu]] which is only for Muslims.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/liquor-control-bill-how-other-countries-and-cities-in-asia-tackle-drinking|title=Liquor Control Bill: How other countries and cities in Asia tackle drinking|publisher=The Straits Times|date=22 January 2015|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> The [[Pan-Malaysian Islamic Party|Islamic party]] there respect the rights of non-Muslims with non-Muslim establishments -like Chinese restaurants and grocery shops- being excluded from such bans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2014/11/25/husam-alcohol-non-muslims/|title=Husam: Right of non-Muslims to consume alcohol, even in Kelantan|author=Dina Murad|publisher=The Star|date=25 November 2014|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> The federal territory of [[Kuala Lumpur]] has the highest alcohol consumption in the country, followed by the states of [[Sarawak]] in second place and [[Sabah]] in third place.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2013/05/11/sabah-is-3rd-highest-in-alcohol-consumption/|title=Sabah is 3rd highest in alcohol consumption|work=Bernama|publisher=The Star|date=11 May 2013|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref>
In 2016, based on a report released by [[International Organisation of Good Templars]] (IOGT), Malaysia has the third highest tax on alcohol worldwide at 15%, behind [[Norway]] and [[Singapore]] which are predicted to keep increasing.<ref name="alcohol tax">{{cite web|url=http://iogt.org/news/2016/03/03/malaysia-alcohol-tax-set-to-increase/|title=Malaysia: Alcohol Tax Set To Increase|publisher=[[International Organisation of Good Templars]]|date=3 March 2016|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> The country has the 10th largest population of alcohol users worldwide, with an annual spending of [[Malaysian ringgit|RM]]2 billion on alcoholic drinks.<ref name="alcohol tax"/> Prior to the [[Trans-Pacific Partnership]], Malaysia together with [[Vietnam]] plans to drop import [[tariff]]s on beer, whiskey and other alcoholic drinks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://asia.nikkei.com/Politics-Economy/Economy/Malaysia-Vietnam-to-drop-import-duties-on-beer-liquor|title=Malaysia, Vietnam to drop import duties on beer, liquor|publisher=Nikkei Asian Review|date=20 October 2015|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref>
== History and tradition == [[File:KgKuaiKandazon Sabah Monsopiad-Cultural-Village-12.jpg|thumb|left|Jars for the making of the traditional [[rice wine]] of ''tapai'' in Sabah.]] The history of local alcoholic drinks in the country are mostly concentrated in the island of [[Borneo]] as the indigenous people in the island have been traditionally drinking a home-made [[rice wine]] called [[tuak]] and [[tapai]] in their communal gatherings and harvest festivals of [[Gawai Dayak]] and [[Kaamatan]].<ref name="alcohol history">{{cite web|url=http://apapaonline.org/data/National_Data/Malaysia/Country_Profile_Alcohol_Malaysia.pdf |title=Country Profile on Alcohol in Malaysia |author1=David H Jernigan |author2=Saroja K Indran |publisher=Asia Pacific Alcohol Policy Alliance |accessdate=26 October 2016 |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026091316/http://apapaonline.org/data/National_Data/Malaysia/Country_Profile_Alcohol_Malaysia.pdf |archivedate=26 October 2016 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> The consumption in the [[Malay Peninsula]] meanwhile are less since the Malay sultanates there adheres to Islamic principles regarding to alcohol.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ukm.my/penerbit/akademika/ACROBATAKADEMIKA72/akademika72[02].pdf|title=Negotiating Ethnic Identities: Alcohol as a Social Marker in East and West Malaysia|author=Stimo Kortteinen|publisher=[[Universiti Kebangsaan Malaysia]] (UKM)|year=2008|accessdate=26 October 2016|format=PDF}}</ref> But following the arrival of alcoholic drinks from the [[Western world]] to [[Malay Archipelago]] in the 17th century when European colonial merchants began to come in contact with the people in the archipelago, some local Malay population start to taste wine brought by the [[Portuguese Empire|Portuguese]] and [[Dutch Empire|Dutch]] and this was continued until the arrival of [[British Empire|British]] until the 19th and 20th centuries.<ref name="alcohol history"/> The arrival of Indian labours in British plantations during the colonial times marks the introduction of "toddy" production by the Indian community, as well with the arrival of Chinese labourers on British mines who produce and introduce their own alcoholic drink such as "samsu" to the local community. The British also brought their own drinking traditions with the introduction of beer and [[stout]]. In the 1930, the first brewery was established in neighbouring [[British Singapore]].<ref name="alcohol history"/>
== Industry and products == {{see also|Beer in Malaysia}} Since the British colonial times, Tiger Beer was the first commercial beer brewed in 1932 by [[Heineken Asia Pacific|Malayan Breweries Limited]], a Singapore-based brewery which was formed from a merger between [[Heineken International|Heineken]] and [[Fraser and Neave]] (F&N).<ref name="MY beer">{{cite web|url=http://www.star2.com/food/food-news/2015/10/17/6-things-you-need-to-know-about-beer-in-malaysia/|title=6 things you need to know about beer in Malaysia|author=Michael Cheang|publisher=Star2|date=17 October 2015|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> The beginning of alcohol productions in Malaysia start in 1968, when two leading breweries of [[Guinness]] and Malayan Breweries merged to form a new company known as [[Guinness Anchor Berhad]]. In 1970, [[Carlsberg Group|Carlsberg]] established its first brewery outside [[Kuala Lumpur]].<ref name="alcohol history"/> Both are since the only legal commercial breweries in Malaysia, which account for 95% of the total beer and stout volume in the country market. In 2007, another two breweries known as Napex and [[Jaz (beer)|Jaz]] brewed beer for pubs in the country, but both have since ceased from operation.<ref name="MY beer"/> Beside local productions, many alcoholic drinks in the country are also imported from neighbouring countries such as Singapore, [[Thailand]], [[Indonesia]], [[Philippines]] and [[Vietnam]].
== Regulation == [[File:Papar Sabah Non-Halal-Corner-in-Giant-Supermarket-01.jpg|thumb|right|Alcoholic drinks been put in a separate storage places with a label "non-halal" in the [[Giant Hypermarket|Giant Supermarket]] of Sabah.]] Alcohol is generally prohibited for Muslim consumers in the country as Malaysia's [[sharia]] law forbids Muslim from drinking and selling alcohol to them. Alcohol is mostly banned for Muslims in the states of [[Kelantan]] and [[Terengganu]]. The [[Legal drinking age|legal age drinking]] for Malaysia is 21 years old and above, which was changed from the previous legal drinking age of 18, as of 1 December 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/06/149036/minimum-drinking-age-raised-21-effective-2017|title=Minimum drinking age raised to 21, effective 2017|author=Fazleena Aziz|publisher=New Straits Times|date=1 June 2016|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/asia/se-asia/malaysia-to-raise-minimum-age-for-alcohol-consumption-to-21-from-the-current-18|title=Malaysia to raise minimum age for alcohol consumption to 21, from the current 18|publisher=The Straits Times|date=1 June 2016|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> The legal limit for alcohol while driving in Malaysia is 80 milligrams per decilitre or 100 millilitres.<ref name="alcohol policies">{{cite web|url=http://traveltips.usatoday.com/alcohol-policies-malaysia-108164.html|title=Alcohol Policies in Malaysia|author=Jason Cristiano Ramon|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> Any vendors, restaurants and retailers need a license to serve or sell tap/draft beers, liquor and spirits in the country, but bottled and canned beers are exempted from such license requirements which is why it is common to find many vendors and coffee houses continue to serving alcohol in their premises without any license throughout the country.<ref name="alcohol policies"/> Malaysia also impose a nationwide regulations for vendors to place their alcoholic drinks into separate refrigerators or storage places, although this was opposed by certain vendors in the state of [[Penang]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/coffee-shop-restaurant-owners-against-separate-storage-space-for-alcohol|title=Coffee shop, restaurant owners against separate storage space for alcohol|author=V. Sivaji|publisher=The Malay Mail|date=25 October 2016|accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> The high tax on alcohol has led to the increase price of alcoholic drinks in Malaysia, this has contributed to alcohol-related harm as many indigenous in the interior turn to unsafe alcohol that being smuggled from neighbouring countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://alcalc.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2016/02/21/alcalc.agw005|title=Unrecorded Alcohol and Alcohol-Related Harm in Rural Sabah, Malaysia: A Socio-economically Deprived Region with Expensive Beer and Cheap Local Spirits|author1=Wendy Diana Shoesmith|author2=Naing Oo Tha|author3=Khin Saw Naing|author4=Roslee Bin Haji Abbas|author5=Ahmad Faris Abdullah|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|date=21 February 2016|accessdate=26 October 2016|doi=10.1093/alcalc/agw005}}</ref>
== See also == {{portal|Drink|Malaysia}} * [[Alcohol in Australia]] * [[Alcohol in Indonesia]] * [[Alcohol in New Zealand]]
== References == {{commons category|Alcoholic beverages from Malaysia}} <references />

{{Infobox adult biography | name = Anna Jean Ayres | image = [[File:Jean Photos-1.jpg|200px|Anna Jean Ayres]] | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date|1920|1|18}} | birth_place = [[Visalia, California]] | baptised = | disappeared_date = | disappeared_place = | disappeared_status = | death_date = {{Death date and age|1988|12|16|1920|1|18}} | death_place = [[Los Angeles]] | death_cause = | body_discovered = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = Developmental psychologist | notable_works = Sensory Integration and Learning Disorders (1972) | style = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = | denomination = | criminal_charge = | criminal_penalty = | criminal_status = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | number_of_films = | website = }}
'''Anna Jean Ayres''' (January 18, 1920 – December 16, 1988) was an American [[occupational therapist]], [[educational psychologist]] and advocate for individuals with special needs. She became known for her work on [[sensory integration]] (SI) theory.<ref name="Sensory integration">{{cite book|last1=Murray|first1=Anita C.|last2=Lane|first2=Shelly J.|last3=Murray|first3=Elizabeth A.|title=Sensory integration.|date=2001|publisher=F.A. Davis|location=Philadelphia|isbn=0-8036-0545-5|edition=2.}}</ref>
==Education== Born on a walnut farm in [[Visalia, California]] in 1920, Ayres' parents, Fletcher and Louise (Stamm) Ayres, were both school teachers.<ref>Nancy A. Erwin "A. Jean Ayres; Notes on Her Life"</ref> Growing up, Ayres claimed to have symptoms similar to the dysfunctions she would later study.<ref name=LATimes>The Times Mirror Company; Los Angeles Times. (1989) "Dr. A. Jean Ayres; Led in Treating Neurological Disorder"</ref> Ayres received her [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] in [[occupational therapy]] in 1945, her [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] in occupational therapy in 1954, and her [[PhD]] in [[educational psychology]] in 1961, all from the [[University of Southern California]] in [[Los Angeles]]. She began her post-doctoral work in the [[UCLA]] Brain Research Institute from 1964 to 1966 under [[Arthur H. Parmelee|Dr. Arthur Parmelee]].<ref name=LATimes/> She was also a faculty member in the occupational therapy and special education departments at the University of Southern California from 1955 to 1984.
Ayres wrote two books and more than thirty journal articles. In 1975 she standardized tests originally known as the ''Southern California Sensory Integration Tests'' and later revised the ''Sensory Integration and Praxis Tests'' in 1989.
In 1976, Ayres founded a private pediatric practice called the Ayres Clinic in [[Torrance, California]] where she conducted [[occupational therapy]] assessment and intervention on children and adults with a variety of disorders, including [[learning disabilities]] and [[autism]].
== Development of Sensory Integration theory ==
===Sensory Integration Dysfunction=== {{main article|Sensory Integration Dysfunction}} {{see also|Sensory processing disorder}} Building on the work of [[Charles S. Sherrington]] and others, she began developing the theory and associated intervention techniques of sensory integration in the 1950s by examining the relationship between the brain and behavior. By the 1960s, Dr. Ayres recognized and described “hidden disabilities” or “dysfunction in sensory integrative processes" (Ayres, 1963, 1968), which she later referred to as ''sensory integrative dysfunction''.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite book|last1=Crepeau|first1=E. B.|last2=Cohn|first2=E. S.|last3=Boyt Schell|first3=B.|title=Willard & Spackman's occupational therapy.|date=2009|publisher=Wolters Kluwer Health/Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|location=Philadelphia|isbn=978-0-7817-6004-1|pages=792–817|edition=11th}}</ref> She originated the theory to “explain the relationship between deficits in interpreting sensation from the body and the environment and difficulties with academic or motor learning.”<ref name="Sensory integration"/> Between 1968 and 1989, Ayres used tests of sensory integrative and practical functions with children with and without learning and sensorimotor difficulties. These were originally published as "Southern California Sensory Integration Tests" (SCSIT; 1975) and later revised as "Sensory Integration and Praxis Tests (SIPT; 1989).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mailloux|first1=Zoe|title=An Overview of the Sensory Integration and Praxis Tests |journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy| date=1990|volume = 44| number = 7| pages= 589–594| doi=10.5014/ajot.44.7.589}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Glennon|first1=Tara|title=Sensory Integration and Praxis Test |journal=Encyclopedia of Autism Disorders| date=2013|pages= 2791–2795| doi=10.1007/978-1-4419-1698-3_1200| <!--print ISBN=978-1-4419-1697-6--->| <!--online -->ISBN= 978-1-4419-1698-3}}</ref> She published numerous factor analyses of assessment findings that allowed her to identify patterns of sensory integrative dysfunction,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ayres|first1=A. Jean|title=Characteristics of Types of Sensory Integration Dysfunction|journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy|date=1971|volume=25|number=7|pages=329–334}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Ayres|first1=A. Jean|title=Sensory integration and Praxis Tests. Manual |date=1989|publisher=WPS |location=Los Angeles, CA |isbn=978-0874243031}}</ref> which were later confirmed by other researchers<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mulligan| first1=Shelley |title= Patterns of sensory integration dysfunction: A confirmatory factor analysis|journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy| date=1998|volume = 52| number = 10| pages= 819–828| doi=10.5014/ajot.52.10.819}}</ref><ref name="Susanne S 2011">{{cite journal|last1=Mailloux|first1=Zoe|last2= Mulligan|first2= Shelley|last3= Roley|first3= Susanne S.|last4= Blanche|first4= Erna I.|last5= Cermak|first5= Sharon|title= Verification and clarification of patterns of sensory integrative dysfunction|journal= American Journal of Occupational Therapy|date=2011|volume = 65| number = 2| pages= 143–151|doi=10.5014/ajot.2011.000752}}</ref> and expanded upon (e.g. in the context of [[ADHD|attention deficit and hyperactivity disorder]]<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mulligan| first1=Shelley |title=An Analysis of Score Patterns of Children With Attention Disorders on the Sensory Integration and Praxis Tests |journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy| date=1996|volume = 50| number =8| pages= 647–654| doi=10.5014/ajot.50.8.647}}</ref>).
===Sensory Integration=== “Sensory integration theory is used to explain why individuals behave in particular ways, plan intervention to ameliorate particular difficulties, and predict how behavior will change as a result of intervention” (p. 5).<ref name="Sensory integration"/> Dr Ayres defined sensory integration as "the organization of sensations for use. Our senses give us information about the physical conditions of our body and the environment around us... The brain must organize all of our sensations if a person is to move and learn and behave in a productive manner" (p. 5).<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
Ayres published her definition of "sensory integration" in 1972 as ''the neurological process that organizes sensation from one’s own body and from the environment and makes it possible to use the body effectively within the environment'' (p. 11).<ref>{{cite book|last1=Ayres|first1=A. Jean|title=Sensory integration and Learning Disorders |date=1972|publisher=WPS |location=Los Angeles, CA |isbn=978-0874243031}}</ref> In 1979, Dr. Ayres published ''Sensory Integration and the Child'', a book to “help parents to recognize sensory integrative problems in their child, understand what is going on, and do something to help their child”<ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite book|last1=Ayres|first1=A. Jean|title=Sensory integration and the child : understanding hidden sensory challenges|date=2005|publisher=WPS|location=Los Angeles, CA|isbn=978-087424-437-3|edition=25th anniversary ed., rev. and updated / by Pediatric Therapy Network}}</ref>
===Sensory Integration Therapy=== As an intervention approach, [[Sensory integration therapy]] is used as “a clinical frame of reference for the assessment and treatment of people who have functional disorders in sensory processing” (p. 325).<ref name="Parham, D. 2010 pp 325-372"/> Ayres considered sensory integration intervention "a speciality of occupational therapy" (Ayres 1979, p. 155). Thus, the assessment and intervention from a sensory integration perspective are most commonly used by occupational therapy practitioners in their treatment of children with difficulties in occupational performance and participation related to sensory integrative or sensory processing dysfunction.
She developed the intervention approach through empirical research<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ayres| first1=A. Jean |title= Proprioceptive Facilitation Elicited Through the Upper Extremities |journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy| date=1955|volume = 9| number = 1| pages= 1–9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ayres| first1=A. Jean |title= Effects of sensory integrative therapy on the coordination of children with choreoathetoid movements |journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy| date=1977|volume = 31| number = 5| pages= 291–293}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ayres| first1=A. Jean |title= Improving Academic Scores Through Sensory Integration| journal=Journal of Learning Disabilities| date=1972|volume = 5| number = 6| pages= 338–343| doi=10.1177/002221947200500605}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ayres| first1=A. Jean |last2=Heskett|first2=William| title= Sensory Integrative Dysfunction in a Schizophrenic Girl|journal=Journal of Autism and Childhood Schizophrenia| date=1972|volume = 2| number = 2| pages= 174–181| doi=10.1007/bf01537570}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ayres| first1=A. Jean|last2=Mailloux|first2=Zoe |title= Influence of Sensory Integration procedures on Language Development |journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy| date=1981|volume = 35| number = 6| pages= 384–390| doi=10.5014/ajot.35.6.383}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ayres| first1=A. Jean|title= Learning Disabilities and the Vestibular System |journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy| date=1978|volume = 11| number = 1| pages= 33–40}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ayres| first1=A. Jean|last2=Tickle|first2=Linda |title= Over-responsivity to Touch and Vestibular Stimuli as a Predictor of Positive Response to Sensory Integration Procedures by Autistic Children |journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy| date=1980|volume = 34| number = 6| pages= 375–381| doi=10.5014/ajot.34.6.375}}</ref> Many professionals{{who|date=September 2015}} hold that Dr. Ayres created one of the first structures for evidence-based practice in occupational therapy through her theory development (Ayres, 1972), model development (Ayres, 1979-2005), assessment development (Ayres, 1989) and intervention strategies (Ayres, 1972).<ref name="ReferenceC">{{cite journal|last1=Parham|first1=D.|last2=Smith Roley|first2=S.|last3=May-Benson|first3=T.|title=Development of a fidelity measure for research on effectiveness of Ayres Sensory Integration intervention.|journal=American Journal of Occupational Therapy|date=2011|issue=65|pages=133–142|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
A recent review concluded that SIT is "ineffective and that its theoretical underpinnings and assessment practices are unvalidated." Moreover the authors warned that SIT techniques exist "outside the bounds of established evidence-based practice" and that SIT is "quite possible a misuse of limited resources."<ref name=Fads>{{cite | author=Smith, T., Mruzek, D. W., & Mozingo, D. | year=2015 | chapter=Sensory integration therapy. | title=Controversial therapies for autism and intellectual disabilities: Fad, fashion, and science in professional practice | pages=247-269 | editor= Richard M. Foxx, James A. Mulick | url=https://books.google.no/books?hl=en&lr=&id=HY29CgAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PA247&dq=%22miracle+belt%22&ots=5Z7JhQbVd-&sig=M080H8B2U55bT_XHuwIK5oShOKM&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=%22miracle%20belt%22&f=false}}</ref>
Sensory integration theory and practice has been met with resistance within the occupational therapy profession as well as other disciplines.<ref name="Parham, D. 2010 pp 325-372">Parham, D. & Mailloux, Z. (2010). Sensory Integration. In Case-Smith, J. & O’Brien, J. (Eds.), Occupational Therapy For Children (6th ed.). (pp 325-372). Maryland Heights, Missouri: Mosby Elsevier.</ref>
==Awards and recognition== Ayres received numerous honors from the American Occupational Therapy Association (AOTA)--including the [[Eleanor Clarke Slagle Lectureship]], the Award of Merit, and a charter membership in the AOTA Academy of Research—and was named in the Roster of Fellows. She has been described by her students and colleagues as “a pioneer in affective neuroscience” (Schneider, 2005), a “developmental theorist” (Knox, 2005), “one of the original perceptual motor theorists” (Smith Roley, 2005), “a pioneer in our understanding of developmental dyspraxia” (Cermak, 2005), and “an astute observer of human behavior and neurological development” (Bauman, 2005).<ref name="ReferenceA"/>
She was dedicated to the promotion of science-driven intervention strategies leading a better quality of life for people with disabilities and their families. “Her work made major inroads into the understanding of clinical neuroscience, the importance of experience in brain development, the role of tactile defensiveness and sensory modulation disorders as contributors to behavioral disorders, and the impact of sensory registration in autism, among others.”<ref name="ReferenceA" />
{{quote box |width = 100% |border = 1px |align = left |bgcolor = #fff |halign = left |quote = ''If I have been productive, it is partly because I have had the advantage of contact with those with the courage as well as the ability to think independently and along unorthodox lines. It has not been easy for the helping professions to conceive of human behavior as an express of the brain, and they are still struggling to do so… The employing of neural mechanisms to enhance motor development is now well established; the current area of major growth and controversy lies in the use of neurological constructs to aid in understanding and ameliorating cognitive functions such as learning disabilities; the next step may well be a more fruitful attack on emotional and behavior disorders.'' |source = — '''Jean Ayres (1974, p. xi)''' }}
Ayres died from complications of breast cancer on December 16, 1988.

{{DEFAULTSORT:Ayres, Anna Jean}} [[Category:Occupational therapy]] [[Category:American women psychologists]] [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:USC Rossier School of Education alumni]] [[Category:1920 births]] [[Category:1988 deaths]]

'''The antiseptic douche''' was one of the most popular forms of [[birth control]] in the early 1900s. It was similar in function to the conventional vaginal [[douche]], but was filled with a chemical mixture instead of saline. The purpose of using a chemical mixture was to interrupt the path of sperm and stop a woman from getting pregnant.<ref>Reis, Elizabeth. American Sexual Histories. 2nd ed. Blackwell Readers in American Social and Cultural History. Chichester, West Sussex ; Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell, 2012. pg 252.</ref> Family sizes in the previous generations had always been large, with many women having six or more children. Frequent miscarrages and many deaths were also common before modern medicine.<ref>“The Fertility Transition in the United States: Tests of Alternative Hypotheses” in National Bureau of Economic Research, Richard H. Steckel (University of Chicago Press 1992), pg 354.</ref> For these women, being given the hope that there was a reasonably priced and safe alternative to countless pregnancies gave many women something they had never had in the past: control of their bodies and in turn their lives.
== Comstock laws == The [[Comstock laws]], passed in 1873, made the sale and advertisement of birth control information illegal.<ref>McGarry, Molly. "Spectral Sexualities: Nineteenth-Century Spiritualism, Moral Panics, and the Making of U.S. Obscenity Law." Journal of Women's History 12, no. 2 (2000): pg 8.</ref> While the Comstock laws encompassed anything considered [[obscene]], literature and information relating to pregnancy and birth control was very heavily affected, which prevented women from being able to obtain accurate information regarding feminine health.<ref>Reis, Elizabeth. American Sexual Histories. 2nd ed. Blackwell Readers in American Social and Cultural History. Chichester, West Sussex ; Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell, 2012. pg 250.</ref> “It is a crime for anyone, even for the best of reasons and in the greatest need to send or to receive by mail anything that tells ‘where, how or of whom’ information may be secured as to how conception may be controlled.”<ref>Foster, Thomas A., and D'Emilio, John. Documenting Intimate Matters: Primary Sources for a History of Sexuality in America. 2012. pg 125.</ref> Even though information could not be advertised, companies found loopholes in the laws. For instance, the packaging of birth control products could not say, “to prevent pregnancy,” but could say to, “manage feminine health.” However, women knew that managing feminine health meant pregnancy prevention, and these products flew off the shelves.<ref>Reis, Elizabeth. American Sexual Histories. 2nd ed. Blackwell Readers in American Social and Cultural History. Chichester, West Sussex ; Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell, 2012. pg 260-261.</ref> As a result of this strategic advertising, an entirely new space in the consumer market was created for birth control products practically overnight. These products, the most successful of which was the antiseptic douche, were sold in catalogs, grocery stores, department stores, and even door to door.
== Success rate in preventing unwanted pregnancy == “This class of case is so common that I feel like apologizing for referring to it… [she] had given birth to five children… And the fear of another pregnancy became an obsession to her.”<ref>Foster, Thomas A., and D'Emilio, John. Documenting Intimate Matters: Primary Sources for a History of Sexuality in America. 2012. pg 121.</ref> Women were desperate and would go to great lengths to prevent an unwanted pregnancy. The Antiseptic Douche, in fact, had one of the lowest success rates, somewhere around 20-30%. The majority of women who used the douche often found themselves pregnant in the long run.<ref>Reis, Elizabeth. American Sexual Histories. 2nd ed. Blackwell Readers in American Social and Cultural History. Chichester, West Sussex ; Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell, 2012. pg 252.</ref> However, regardless of the high failure rate, demand was high. Because the products could not be advertised as birth control products, the companies were not responsible to communicate the success rate or the health risks associated with using an antiseptic douche. “Clamoring for a larger share of the hygiene market, manufactures did their utmost to ensure their product would be one women would want to try.”<ref>Reis, Elizabeth. American Sexual Histories. 2nd ed. Blackwell Readers in American Social and Cultural History. Chichester, West Sussex ; Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell, 2012. pg 254.</ref> Later research actually shows that douching can lead to pregnancy, in that the solution can push the sperm farther up into the body and into the [[Cervix]], or in most cases do nothing because even when used correctly and immediately after sexual intercourse, the sperm has already reached the egg.
== Health risks == Modern research shows douching is very unhealthy for a woman’s hygiene. It unbalances a woman’s [[pH]], which is self-cleaning.<ref>The Office of Women's Health. Women's Health, “Douching.” 2015. pg 1.</ref> Many antiseptic douche products being sold at the time contained very strong chemicals, such as [[Mercury (Element)|Mercury]], and packaging provided little information on how to reduce the effect of the chemicals. Many women felt that the stronger the mixture, the more likely it would be to prevent pregnancy, which increased the health risks. In addition to Mercury, there were various other chemicals being used as birth control, and these different solutions could result in burns to a woman’s vagina, [[Ectopic pregnancy|Ectopic pregnancies]], and other serious effects that could potentially lead to hospitalization.<ref>Reis, Elizabeth. American Sexual Histories. 2nd ed. Blackwell Readers in American Social and Cultural History. Chichester, West Sussex ; Malden, MA: Wiley-Blackwell, 2012. pg 252.</ref> == Decline in use of antiseptic douching == With the repeal of the Comstock Act, the continued championing of Margaret Sanger, and the development of more reliable forms of birth control, the use of the Antiseptic Douche began to decline. Over time more information was made available to women about the damaging effects of douching, spread by organizations such as [[Planned Parenthood]].<ref>The Office of Women's Health. Women's Health, “Douching.” 2015. pg 2.</ref> With the repeal of the Comstock Act also brought about the development of the birth control pill, which revolutionized women's health. The success rate and ease of new forms of birth control also influenced the decline in the reliance of Antiseptic Douching.
